cards.title: Cricket / India dominate wicketless Bangladesh on first day of one-off Test
cards.rawTitle: India dominate wicketless Bangladesh on first day of one-off Test

item.title: India dominate Bangladesh on first day of one-off Test
item.trailText: Shikhar Dhawan and Murali Vijay shared a record-breaking unbeaten partnership as India moved into a commanding position against Bangladesh
item.standFirst:
• Shikhar Dhawan and Murali Vijay rack up 239
• Hosts unable to disrupt record-breaking partnership
item.body:
Shikhar Dhawan and Murali Vijay shared a record-breaking unbeaten partnership as India moved into a commanding position on a rain-affected first day of the one-off Test against Bangladesh.

Only 56 overs were possible at Fatullah because of the weather but India made the most of them, racking up a first-wicket partnership against the Tigers of 239 with Dhawan leading the way.

The recalled opener reached 150 not out at the close from just 158 balls, with Vijay alongside him on a more pedestrian 89 from 178.

Dhawan was not the only restored performer for India as Harbhajan Singh was selected to play in his 102nd Test after an absence of just over two years.

The wicketkeeper Litton Das was handed a debut for Bangladesh, with the captain Mushfiqur Rahim unable to take his place behind the stumps because of a finger injury, and was put straight to work as India won the toss and elected to bat on a pitch expected to turn more as the match goes on.

Soumya Sarkar had an early lbw appeal turned down against Vijay while Dhawan got a thick outside edge that did not carry in the following over, but that was as good as it got in the early stages for the home side as Dhawan got to work.

The returning opener was scoring at will, peppering the boundary, and brought up his half-century in just 47 balls with 10 fours. Vijay had been happy to let his partner do most of the work but fours in consecutive overs took him into double figures.

The hundred was brought up off 134 balls as drizzle began to fall and there was just time for Shuvagata Hom to put down a tough chance to dismiss Dhawan at short midwicket before the players came off at 107 without loss.

Nearly four hours then passed as both lunch and tea came and went but when play resumed the tourists picked up where they had left off.

India continued to find the rope with relative ease and Vijay brought up his half-century off 98 balls with a four.

Dhawan reached three figures as he swept his 101st ball to the boundary for his 16th four and India were utterly dominant at 167 without loss at drinks.

They went past 175 to break the record and Vijay then brought up the 200 in 259 balls with a six.

Vijay survived an lbw appeal against Hom but progress was generally serene for India as Dhawan brought up his 150 off the last ball before bad light ended play.

displayImages.caption: India's Murali Vijay, right, congratulates Shikhar Dhawan on reaching his century. Photograph: A.M. Ahad/AP
displayImages.cleanCaption: India's Murali Vijay, right, congratulates Shikhar Dhawan on reaching his century. Photograph: A.M. Ahad/AP

headerImage.caption: India’s Murali Vijay, right, congratulates Shikhar Dhawan on reaching his century. Photograph: AM Ahad/AP
headerImage.cleanCaption: India’s Murali Vijay, right, congratulates Shikhar Dhawan on reaching his century. Photograph: AM Ahad/AP

sublinks.title: Australia / Rogers to miss second Test against West Indies due to concussion
sublinks.rawTitle: Rogers to miss second Test against West Indies due to concussion

item.title: Chris Rogers to miss Second Test against West Indies due to concussion
item.trailText: Australia opening batsman Chris Rogers will go into the Ashes series short of match fitness after being ruled out for a second consecutive test due to concussion
item.standFirst: • Australian opening batsman Rogers ruled out by doctor
item.body:
Australia opening batsman Chris Rogers will go into the Ashes series short of match fitness after being ruled out for a second consecutive test against West Indies due to concussion.

Rogers missed the opening match in Dominica after being struck on the helmet by a ball in training and team doctor Peter Brukner said he had not recovered sufficiently to be selected for the second and final test in Kingston starting on Thursday.

After finishing in Jamaica, Australia head to England for the five-test Ashes series, starting with the first match in Cardiff on July 8.

“Chris has improved but he is still not 100 percent so we are restricting his training (and) therefore he is unavailable for selection for the second test,” Brukner said on Cricket Australia’s website.

“While most concussions resolve within a week there is a significant number who remain symptomatic and require a longer period of recovery.

“Unfortunately Chris is in this category. We will continue to monitor his progress and hopefully it will not be too long before he is back to full training.“

Shaun Marsh batted in the 37-year-old’s place in the nine-wicket win in Dominica, scoring 19 and 13 not out.

Selectors have yet to name a team but left-hander Marsh is likely to retain his place, despite his limited contribution in the first test.

While Australia trounced the hosts in three days at Windsor Park their traditional struggles against spin continued.

West Indies legspinner Devendra Bishoo capturing six wickets in the first innings, including three top order batsmen.

One of Bishoo’s victims was Steven Smith, considered one of Australia’s best players of spin. Smith said he hoped Australia’s top six batsmen would handle the conditions better at Sabina Park.

“I think it’s always quite hard coming from Australia to play over here where guys are able to get the ball out of the front of the hand and still get a lot of spin,” he wrote in a column on CA’s website.

“I guess that’s traditionally what we’re not used to being from Australia. But I think the guys are learning how to play in these conditions.

“Obviously it didn’t go to plan with the top order but I think that’s one thing we’ll continue to address and hopefully the top six are the guys in the runs during the next test.”

headerImage.caption: Chris Rogers bats as Peter Nevill of Australia keeps wicket during an Australian nets session in Roseau, Dominica.  Photograph: Ryan Pierse/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Chris Rogers bats as Peter Nevill of Australia keeps wicket during an Australian nets session in Roseau, Dominica.

image.caption: India's Murali Vijay, right, congratulates Shikhar Dhawan on reaching his century. Photograph: A.M. Ahad/AP
image.cleanCaption: India's Murali Vijay, right, congratulates Shikhar Dhawan on reaching his century. Photograph: A.M. Ahad/AP

cards.title: Football / Diaby and Johnson among released Premier League players
cards.rawTitle: Diaby and Johnson among released Premier League players

item.title: Abou Diaby and Glen Johnson among released Premier League players
item.trailText: Abou Diaby, Sylvain Distin, Glen Johnson and Jonás Gutiérrez are among the high-profile names who have been included on Premier League clubs’ released players list
item.standFirst:
• Sylvain Distin and Jonás Gutiérrez also officially let go by current employers
• Some listed players, such as Wes Brown, likely to be offered a fresh contract
item.body:
Abou Diaby, Sylvain Distin, Glen Johnson and Jonás Gutiérrez are among the high-profile names who have been included on Premier League clubs’ released players list.

The 20 clubs – as of the 2014/15 season – are required to submit their retained and released lists to the Premier League by the third Saturday in May. They are not definite given some of the named players are likely to be offered fresh contracts with their current employers having seen their existing deals end. But in many cases, it is a case of thank you and goodbye .

That is certainly the case for Diaby, who made only 124 appearances for Arsenal having signed from Auxerre in 2006 due to persistent and serious injury problems.

Related: Ryan Taylor: Newcastle United released me and Jonas Gutiérrez on phone

Everton have confirmed Distin, who joined them in 2009, is definitely leaving the club, alongside Antolín Alcaraz, while Johnson is definitely on his way out of Liverpool having also arrived on Merseyside in 2009. He is joined at the Anfield exit door by Australian goalkeeper Brad Jones.

Gutiérrez’s departure from Newcastle was confirmed at the end of last month, and after it was revealed that the 31-year-old found out that he was no longer wanted at St James’ Park via a second-hand phone call.

Ron Vlaar and Wes Brown are also on the released players’ list but are among those who are likely to be offered new contracts by their current clubs.

sublinks.title: Chelsea / Mourinho hints at complicating any Cech deal with Arsenal
sublinks.rawTitle: Mourinho hints at complicating any Cech deal with Arsenal

item.title: José Mourinho hints at complicating any Petr Cech deal with Arsenal
item.trailText: Chelsea’s manager José Mourinho has hinted at complicating any Peter Cech to Arsenal deal and would like his pick of the Gunners squad
item.standFirst:
• Chelsea manager would like his pick of Gunners squad
• Mourinho accepts that Abramovich will have final word
item.body:
José Mourinho has warned that he could complicate any attempt by Arsenal to take Petr Cech to the Emirates by insisting that Arsène Wenger send a player to Stamford Bridge in return.

Mourinho accepts that his employer, Roman Abramovich, can grant Cech permission to move to any club the goalkeeper wishes as a reward for a decade of service at Chelsea – and Cech this week hinted at a preference for Arsenal by intimating he would like to remain in London – but the manager added with a mischievous smile that he could still add a twist to any deal that Arsenal hope to do.

Related: Chelsea’s José Mourinho repeats ‘corruption’ claims over 2012 coach vote

“My answer is not important because the owner is the owner, he is the person with the perspective I admire a lot, respect a lot,” said Mourinho. “He respects a lot of people who do important things for him. Since 2004 to 2014-15, Cech has had 10 years of success with the club, 10 years of unbelievable behaviour. I will have to accept any decision that the owner has. I’m different. I have the same respect for Petr that everybody at the club has, but my answer [to a proposed move to Arsenal] would be: ‘No way.’ If the answer is different I will accept that. But at every club that is interested in Petr I can find a player that I like in that team, too.”

Mourinho added that he aims to recruit three players this summer to ensure his Premier League-winning team do not lose their appetite. He also expressed his satisfaction that none of his key men are likely to leave. “I think [the most important business] is done, which is to keep the players I want to keep. In other seasons I was very happy to sell a few players, even good players. This season I’m not happy to sell my best players so that is the real challenge to keep them.

“If I keep Hazard and Matic and Ivanovic and Diego Costa, Fàbregas; if I keep all of these important players for us that’s the first target. I think then we need three players. A striker, because we lost our legend [Didier Drogba], a defender and a midfield player. Give a little bit more competitiveness to the squad, bring some new blood in, put some players a little bit under pressure. They know they have someone waiting, I need that to support my way of working. Now they’re the champions I need that. But basically [Chelsea will have] the same squad, the same team, the same manager, stability in the club.”

Mourinho, speaking at BT Sport studios at an event to announce that he will provide analysis for the channel as it begins exclusive live coverage of the Champions League and Europa League, also called for the introduction of a winter break to help English sides go farther in European competitions.

The Chelsea manager believes they arrive at the knockout stages of tournaments more drained than their European counterparts and would like the Premier League to pause in January, allowing players to recharge without sacrificing traditional festive period fixtures.

“I love our football in December,” said Mourinho. “But the reality is that when the other teams are coming into the second part of the Champions League they are very fresh after a good rest; after a second pre-season they are not tired. We are sometimes physically and mentally tired and it is more difficult for English clubs. English clubs did it in the past and will do in the future but it is more difficult for us. We could do something after the new year. We can still play five or six matches in two weeks – amazing Boxing Day matches and so on – but after that we should do something to give the players a little bit of a break.”

displayImages.caption: Chelsea's Petr Cech claims a cross against Arsenal in a league game at the Emirates Stadium. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

cards.title: Talking Horses / Wednesday’s best bets plus all the latest racing news
cards.rawTitle: Wednesday’s best bets plus all the latest racing news

item.title: Talking Horses: Wednesday’s best bets plus the latest racing news
item.trailText: Chris Cook and Tony Paley: Cirrus Des Aigles will miss the Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud clash with Treve later this month after suffering a minor setback
item.standFirst: Cirrus Des Aigles will miss the Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud clash with Treve later this month after suffering a minor setback
item.body:
11.20am Cirrus Des Aigles will miss Treve clash after setback

Tony Paley: Cirrus Des Aigles will miss his much-anticipated clash with Treve in the Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud later this month after suffering a minor setback.

Trainer Corine Barande-Barbe said: “It’s just a little problem with his leg, it’s very, very small but it just means that we cannot work him at the moment. It’s nothing serious, just a little bump and a bruise but it will prevent him from running in the Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud.

“With a horse like him who gives everything in his work and racing, you have to be sure everything is 100 per cent otherwise you can have serious problems. He can only do light work for a few weeks now so I think he will be off until the end of July.”

Cirrus Des Aigles has won seven Group Ones and Barande-Barbe has raised the possibility of trying to add an Irish success to his tally when he is back to full strength later in the year.

She added: “It is difficult to say when he will be back and where he will go, but we have not forgotten about the Irish Champion Stakes. Maybe he will have a race before that, we will have to see, but that could be an option.”

Wednesday’s best bets, by Chris Cook

So, £11m for a new all-weather track. It seems an enormous sum of money but a hard-nosed business like ARC is hardly likely to take a flier on something like that, so we must imagine they expect to make a long-term profit from their resurfacing at Newcastle.

Everyone else in racing is mulling the use to which they could have put that £11m. I wonder how much it would cost to reopen this old place. I don’t suppose the idea appeals to many jockeys but I have a feeling it would attract spectators.

The resurgence of Pat Dobbs continues, the veteran jockey riding a double at Salisbury yesterday, three days after the first Group One win of his 18-year career. Richard Hannon may have put him aboard another winner in Steal The Scene (3.10) at Haydock.

This one won a handicap at the fifth attempt at Leicester a fortnight ago, with a degree of comfort that suggested the switch to a fast surface made a big difference for him. He’s up 8lb, although that still only puts him 3lb ahead of the initial rating he got after his maiden win in August and he looks one to stick with, so long as Haydock’s expected good to firm turns out to be just that. He’s 5-1 as I type.

In the following race, Birdman (3.40) may be able to resume winning ways at 9-2. He won his first three after joining David O’Meara this year but was then beaten on soft ground at Ripon, having arguably been given a bit much to do.

He’s still more than a stone below his peak rating and I can see him scoring again, now that he’s back on fast ground and the jockey is hopefully satisfied that he can trust the horse’s stamina.

I’m surprised to be getting 7-1 about Ski Slope (8.10) for the familiar Hannon and Richard Hughes combination at Kempton tonight. She didn’t get a clear run and stayed on into fifth on her Salisbury reappearance, which is, I concede, not the most inspiring effort.

But Hannon horses can come on plenty for their reappearance run and this filly was having her first start for 11 months. One month later, she should be quite a bit straighter and I don’t think she’s harshly weighted. She won her maiden on Polytrack, at Lingfield.

Tipping competition, day three

Our winners so far:

Monday

Tiger Jim 15-2

Dawn’s Early Light 9-1

Foxtrot Knight 7-2

Tuesday

Maybelater 6-1

Perfect Bounty 7-2

Cyflymder 11-4

And our leader is …

yasmin11 +19.25

… who has had four winners out of six so far, including Maybelater and Cyflymder yesterday. The same double was achieved by budgie27 (+14.75), who lies second, while jamesstod (+10) is third.

Today, we’d like your tips, please, for these races: 3.40 Haydock, 5.10 Haydock, 7.50 Hamilton.

This week’s prize is a pair of tickets to Cartmel for Sunday 28 June, which, I’m told by the course, is their first ever Sunday fixture! So you’ll witness a bit of history, as every other British track has already raced on a Sunday at some point. The day has been billed as Big Top Racing because there’s a circus on the site that weekend offering free performances for racegoers before and after racing. Those of you who don’t win can buy tickets here.

As ever, our champion will be the tipster who returns the best profit to notional level stakes of £1 at starting price on our nominated races, of which there will be three each day up until Friday. Non-runners count as losers. If you have not joined in so far this week, you are welcome to do so today, but you will start on -6.

In the event of a tie at the end of the week, the winner will be the tipster who, from among those tied on the highest score, posted their tips earliest on the final day.

For terms and conditions click here.

Good luck!

Click here for all the day’s racecards, form, stats and results.

And post your tips or racing-related comments below.

sublinks.title: Horse racing / Trainers condemn Newcastle’s all-weather track plans
sublinks.rawTitle: Trainers condemn Newcastle’s all-weather track plans

item.title: Trainers line up to condemn Newcastle’s all-weather track plans
item.trailText: Newmarket handler Ed Vaughan has described the ripping up of the turf course at the north-east track as an act of vandalism
item.standFirst:
• Ed Vaughan describes ripping up of turf course as act of vandalism
• Famous Northumberland Plate will be run on likely Tapeta surface
• BHA must back the opposition to tearing up Flat turf course
item.body:
Newcastle will stage its final Flat races on turf in September and will reopen as an all-weather track next spring after an £11m redevelopment, it was announced on Tuesday. The plans have been held for a long time by Newcastle’s owners, ARC, but were frustrated last year by a technicality in racing’s rules.

That technicality, requiring at least one race beyond a mile on each card, has been overcome by an agreement with racing’s rulers that some twilight or floodlit cards will start earlier than normal, allowing at least one race to be run on the round course while daylight allows. Under present proposals, only the track’s straight mile is to be floodlit.

Newcastle’s turf Flat track has been much praised by trainers and its loss is a cause of sadness and anger to many. Ralph Beckett was one of several who took to Twitter, saying it was “difficult to think of a more depressing announcement for the sport”, while Ed Vaughan described ARC’s plan as “an act of vandalism”. The Yorkshire-based Tim and Mick Easterby also expressed regret and suggested they would rather have seen an all-weather track at Catterick, where rival plans for such a development now seem much less likely to proceed.

William Haggas acknowledged that trainers in the north need an all-weather track closer than Southwell but said: “Surely this isn’t the answer. The only way we can stop it is to not support it. It will have to be a desperate situation for me to go there. Never say never but I certainly won’t be leading trainer there.

“Field sizes will suffer as the horse population shrinks and opportunities increase. You could be a blind man and see that. And this will impact on the all-weather tracks in the south, as the Johnstons and the Faheys won’t come down as they have done.”

Of ARC, which owns or manages 15 tracks, Haggas said: “They will take fixtures there from their other tracks and they’ll close another track eventually, they won’t do it immediately. It’s tragic.”

But Susannah Gill, ARC’s director of external affairs, insisted there were no plans to close any tracks. While accepting that two, Folkestone and Hereford, had been closed soon after ARC was created in a merger in 2012, Gill said “the business is now in a stage of investment”. Some fixtures are likely to be moved from Southwell to Newcastle but Gill said Southwell would remain viable and pointed to planned investment this autumn in the Nottinghamshire track’s flood defences as a sign that it remained part of ARC’s plans.

No opening date has been set for the new Newcastle, as the progress of works will depend on the severity of the coming winter. Its jumps fixtures will be moved elsewhere, with the Fighting Fifth Hurdle expected to be at Doncaster this November, but will then return to Newcastle, where the jumps turf track will remain.

The Northumberland Plate, Newcastle’s most high profile Flat race, will be run on the new surface, likely to be Tapeta, and not on the turf of the jumps course, as had been suggested . Officials decided it would be too expensive to maintain the jumps course through the summer and that the necessary watering might prove detrimental.

The North Yorkshire-based Richard Fahey, who trained last year’s Plate winner, stood out from his rivals in welcoming the news. “I think we need [an all-weather track] and whether that is at Newcastle or not, we had to get one sooner rather than later,” he said. “If no other course wants to take the bull by the horns and set the wheels in motion, I don’t see why it shouldn’t be Newcastle.”

displayImages.caption: Newcastle racegoers will soon see only all-weather racing on the course's turf track. Photograph: Owen Humphreys/PA WIRE
displayImages.cleanCaption: Newcastle racegoers will soon see only all-weather racing on the course's turf track. Photograph: Owen Humphreys/PA WIRE

cards.title: France 1-0 England / Sampson furious after Abily’s elbow goes unpunished
cards.rawTitle: Sampson furious after Abily’s elbow goes unpunished

item.title: England coach Mark Sampson furious as referee misses Camille Abily’s elbow
item.trailText: Sampson said: ‘If you see pictures of her you’ll see what the decision should have been’ after Laura Bassett was elbowed in the face by France’s Camille Abily
item.standFirst:
• France midfielder Abily unpunished for elbowing Laura Bassett in the face
• Sampson: ‘If you see pictures of her you’ll see what decision should have been’
item.byline: Louise Taylor at the Moncton Stadium
item.body:
Mark Sampson has called for improved protection from referees at Canada 2015 after France’s Camille Abily escaped unpunished for a sly elbow to the face that left Laura Bassett with a severely swollen cheek in Tuesday’s Group F opener.

Related: France 1-0 England | Women’s World Cup Group F match report

England’s coach was not blaming his side’s 1-0 defeat on the second-half incident but he was disappointed a red card had not been shown. Sampson said: “If you see Laura Bassett walk out of the stadium or see pictures of her you’ll see what the decision should have been. We were told before the tournament we would be protected and we’re disappointed that we haven’t been in the first game.”

While he was similarly dismayed by England’s latest defeat against a side they haven’t beaten since 1974, Sampson remained determined to take positives from a reverse against a team ranked third in the world.

“The result wasn’t that good, not that good at all,” he said. “But we’ll take lots of positives from the game. We restricted world-class opponents to one goal. The way the team defended, the way they managed the game was outstanding. Our goalkeeper hasn’t had to make world-class saves. We have a platform on which to build momentum. We need to tidy a few things up. But this performance shows who far we’ve come. We’ll learn a lot from it.”

England only had three shots all game – with just one on target – but even that statistic refused to dampen the optimism of a coach who replaced a frequently bold approach with containment tactics and a 4-1-4-1 system.

“We want to score goals and be creative,” said Sampson. “And we need to find some attacking solutions. But we have to respect our opponents. We had a first-half plan to manage the spaces where France can hurt you and I’ve never seen a full-back keep Élodie Thomis as quiet as Claire Rafferty, ably assisted by Lucy Bronze, did at left-back. As we grow into the tournament we’ll find more rhythm.

“We were disappointed to concede a goal scored during a transition when we were trying to counterattack but let’s not take away from the quality of the 20-yard finish. [Eugénie] Le Sommer is a very good player and we’ve been punished with a great finish.

“It was the first game of the tournament, it was as strong a wind as I’ve found in any international and both teams found it hard to progress up the pitch because of it. It was a game of limited chances and the wind made it very difficult. But we can improve.”

Following the defeat, England’s forthcoming Group F games against Mexico in Moncton on Saturday and Colombia in Montreal next Wednesday have become all-important.

Sampson said: “We’ll be prepared to face a very good Mexico team. I know my team, I know exactly how we’ll play. We’re excited and when we take on the big guns again we’ll find a way to win.”

The coach also appealed for possibly underwhelmed English television audiences to “stick with us”, pointing out that England were never out of the game: “We were in it until the end. We were playing a world-class team with a very well-organised physically strong defence and they put five in midfield towards the end.

“It’s disappointing because we felt we could come here and get a win but it was a high quality international. It was a strong England performance. We showed great solidarity and are in excellent physical condition.

“We’ve had to answer question after question about the fitness of certain players but I think we’ve put them to bed now.”

displayImages.caption: France's Camille Abily, right, went unpunished after elbowing England's Laura Bassett in the face during the opening match in Group F. Photograph: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images

sublinks.title: Match report / Le Sommer too hot for England in World Cup opener
sublinks.rawTitle: Le Sommer too hot for England in World Cup opener

item.title: Women’s World Cup 2015: England beaten by France in Group F opener
item.trailText: England were beaten 1-0 by France in their opening World Cup 2015 game in Canada, after a first-half goal from Eugénie Le Sommer
item.standFirst:
• France 1-0 England
• Relive the action with Nick Ames’ MBM report
item.byline: Louise Taylor at the Moncton Stadium
item.body:
Familiarity is so often wonderfully reassuring but it can also provoke acute disappointment. On a day when the wet, windy weather proved rather too quintessentially English for the liking of Mark Sampson’s players, France also proved infuriatingly typical.

England have not beaten their neighbours from across the Channel since 1974 and the slenderness of the scoreline, with the two side’s separated only by Eugénie Le Sommer’s first-half strike, disguises the superiority of a French side now clear favourites to top Group F. Granted Les Bleus could have had Camille Abily sent off for a snide elbow on Laura Bassett but by then victory was all but secured.

While this defeat is not exactly disastrous Sampson will be concerned by the lack of chances his team created and knows that, if they are to progress, England must up their game in subsequent group fixtures against Mexico and Colombia.

The Welshman is big on surprises and true to his reputation as the great rotator of the women’s game, he chose Moncton as the venue for unveiling a brand new England formation. This 4-1-4-1 system featured Lucy Bronze, normally a right-back or central defender, stationed wide on the left of midfield, Ellen White, usually a centre forward, on the right wing and Fara Williams sitting deep in the quasi-sweeping role.

Initially at least it certainly succeeded in fazing a France team deployed in characteristic 4-4-2 guise. Assiduously closed down by Sampson’s personnel, Philippe Bergeroo’s side were at first forced to resort to a series of unusually long, rather aimless, balls.

If Eniola Aluko was struggling in a rather thankless lone attacking role for England, at least Jill Scott was making her presence felt in central midfield. It was largely thanks to Scott that France took time to settle into a familiar slick passing groove in front of a disappointingly small crowd in Moncton.

A 13,000 sellout had been predicted but the ground looked barely half-full with locals largely opting to stay away. This bilingual city in the eastern “Maritime” Canadian province of New Brunswick had appeared the ideal venue for these teams but with dark rain clouds hovering in the humid skies and a capricious wind blowing, the residents of the French speaking suburb of Dieppe and English speaking Riverview had evidently decided to stay indoors.

An initially slow start vindicated their decision but, almost imperceptibly, the entertainment value rose. As the rain shower which had greeted kick-off finally, if temporarily, cleared so France began emerging from their shells. Suddenly remembering how to retain possession, they began moving the ball around too slickly even for Scott.

England’s defence received a warning when Le Sommer unleashed a left foot volley. It was deflected to safety off Alex Scott but shortly afterwards Louisa Nécib showed off a cute dummy and dispatched an awkward cross shot which had Karen Bardsley sprawling to save.

Then came the sort of moment Sampson must have dreaded. Attempting to pass her way out of defence, Bassett played Katie Chapman into trouble and the midfielder swiftly conceded possession to Le Sommer. From 20 yards she proceeded to squeeze a splendid rising shot inside a post.

With Scott and the outstanding Claire Rafferty in particular fighting back, all was not lost. Yet as intelligently as Rafferty, back at left-back following her recovery from a third ruptured cruciate ligament, was defending against the dangerous Élodie Thomis her side were up against it.

Although England did have one first-half scoring chance – shot wide by Chapman – they had Bardsley to thank for reacting smartly to keep Abily’s shot out.

While France continued to rather hog the ball in the second half, England increasingly pacified their key players. Le Sommer, however, simply refused to be subdued and, having forced Bardsley into another decent save she soon directed a volley slightly off target.

In between Gallic interchanges Scott was presented with a shooting chance but could only direct is straight at Sarah Bouhaddi, the France goalkeeper. That was a shame as with Wendie Renard excelling in central defence for her side such openings were always going to be few and far between.

The moment for Sampson to switch things around had arrived and Toni Duggan came on for the selfless White.

England’s coach had made much of his team’s ability to switch to Plan B mid-match and the subsequent introduction of a forward, Fran Kirby, for Alex Scott served to emphasise this.

A shift to 4-3-3 ensued but England were very lucky that Abily’s menacing, seemingly goalbound volley was fortuitously deflected off course by Steph Houghton.

Not that the France bench will have been too upset – it appeared that Abily had elbowed Bassett in the preamble and they were surely relieved to have escaped what could have been a red card.

With Le Sommer withdrawn, France – now with five in midfield – seemed content to hold on for a deceptively narrow win. Such containment tactics can prove high risk but the only threat England could muster was a shot from Aluko which flew high and wide. It seemed entirely emblematic of their afternoon.

displayImages.caption: Eugenie Le Sommer of France (No9) celebrates scoring the winning goal against England in the 2015 Women's World Cup. Photograph: Steve Bardens/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Eugenie Le Sommer of France (No9) celebrates scoring the winning goal
displayImages.cleanCaption: Eugenie Le Sommer of France (No9) celebrates scoring the winning goal against England in the 2015 Women's World Cup. Photograph: Steve Bardens/Fifa via Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Eugenie Le Sommer of France (No9) celebrates scoring the winning goal against England in the 2015 Women's World Cup. Photograph: Steve Bardens/Fifa via Getty Images
headerImage.altText: Eugenie Le Sommer of France (No9) celebrates scoring the winning goal

sublinks.title: Brazil 2 - 0 South Korea / Marta becomes the leading scorer in World Cup history
sublinks.rawTitle: Marta becomes the leading scorer in World Cup history

item.title: Brazil in record-breaking World Cup win against South Korea
item.trailText: Marta scored her 15th career women’s World Cup goal to become the all-time leader in tournament history, leading Brazil to a 2-0 win over South Korea
item.standFirst:
• Brazil 2 - 0 South Korea
  • Marta passes Birgit Prinz’s all-time goal scoring record
  • Formiga becomes oldest scorer in World Cup history
item.body:
Marta scored her 15th career women’s World Cup goal to become the all-time leader in tournament history, leading Brazil to a 2-0 win over South Korea in Montreal on Tuesday.

The five-time world player of the year scored with a penalty in the 53rd minute to put Brazil up 2-0, giving her 15 career World Cup goals and surpassing the 14 goals scored by Germany’s Brigit Prinz.

Marta’s spotkick came after Formiga was fouled by South Korea’s So-hyun Cho inside the box, and she dispatched the penalty into the lower left corner of the net for the record goal.

Formiga had earlier scored Brazil’s first goal, and the 37-year-old became the oldest player to find the net in tournament history doing so in her sixth World Cup.

The win moved Brazil top of Group E after Costa Rica and Spain drew 1-1 earlier in the day.

Brazil play their second group-stage game against Spain on Saturday, while South Korea face Costa Rica.

headerImage.caption: Brazil’s Marta is chased by South Korea’s Shim Seoyeon during a Group E match at the 2015 FIFA Women’s World Cup. Photograph: Nicholas Kamm/AFP/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Brazil’s Marta is chased by South Korea’s Shim Seoyeon during a Group E match at the 2015 FIFA Women’s World Cup.

cards.title: Match report / Buttler and Root blast new-look England to victory
cards.rawTitle: Buttler and Root blast new-look England to victory

item.title: England break records and New Zealand with crushing victory in first ODI
item.trailText: England scored a record 408 as they thrashed New Zealand by 210 runs in the first one-day international at Edgbaston
item.standFirst:
• England 408-9; New Zealand 198
• England win by 210 runs
item.body:
When Eoin Morgan talked of a new-look England, not even he could have expected this. It was a day where records tumbled and New Zealand fumbled, a performance so majestic that – if watched in isolation – it would dupe Trevor Bayliss into thinking he has been given the easiest job in world cricket.

England secured victory in this first of five one-day internationals against New Zealand by a record 210 runs – their biggest margin – in a swashbuckling style that was anathema to the previous regime. Morgan’s side compiled England’s best ODI total of 408 in an innings that will live long in the memory, thanks to superb centuries from Jos Buttler and Joe Root, hitting a record 14 sixes before closing the match out with ease under Birmingham’s evening sun.

Related: England v New Zealand: first ODI – as it happened

It is perhaps too early to herald a new dawn for English one-day cricket but, at the very least, this was a significant step forward from the previous era. England batted fearlessly, looking to attack at every opportunity, yet this was no mere slog-fest, even if the boundaries flowed and the shots dazzled. Buttler and Root produced wonderfully crafted innings before the guile of Steven Finn and Adil Rashid dismissed the tourists for 198.

For all the talk of new blood, it was familiar faces that flourished in the new environment. A penny for Peter Moores’ thoughts as Root and then Buttler tore New Zealand’s attack to shreds, only months after the Black Caps dismantled England so emphatically during the World Cup.

Jason Roy and Sam Billings – the latter making his ODI debut – managed three runs between them, while Roy went for a diamond duck, and it is certainly a damning indictment of the former set-up that those who earlier this year played with such trepidation suddenly appeared so liberated.

“You can look back and say what you want about the World Cup, but I’m looking forward,” said Morgan. “There’s about 90 games until the next World Cup and we need to get some games into this team.”

Roy, playing in his second ODI, dabbed at a full ball outside off-stump and found Martin Guptill at backward point, who took a smart low catch from the first ball of the match. Yet although Roy will undoubtedly be bitterly disappointed, his early dismissal ultimately did not prove costly.

With England two down, having amassed 50 runs, the prospect of such a sizeable total would have been laughed out of the ground. Instead, Root and Morgan were at the crease and Brendon McCullum, never afraid of the unorthodox, was on the attack.

The England captain – and McCullum’s close friend – was his target, having endured a miserable run of form with the bat that coincided with the team’s World Cup malaise. During the early stages of Morgan’s innings here, he faced an aggressive off-side field of a slip, gully, point, short point and cover; yet under pressure he eased England forward. His 121-run partnership alongside Root was a calming influence at a decisive moment.

However, it was Root and then Buttler who undoubtedly stole the show, with Rashid providing a fine cameo. These three innings were certainly polarised in stylistic terms but each contributed significantly to England’s total, as New Zealand floundered in the field where previously on this tour they have appeared so assured.

Root played with stunning poise, the Yorkshireman’s timing flawless through the covers. He may have ridden his luck on a few occasions – edging wide of slip before being dropped in the deep by Ross Taylor – but his was an innings reflective of a man in tremendous form, an unflustered, almost nonchalant, exhibition of one-day batting.

Related: Eoin Morgan hails ‘outstanding’ England victory over New Zealand

Root’s 104 from 78 balls ended when he was caught behind off Trent Boult, the only Kiwi bowler to emerge from this defeat with any credit. But despite losing Ben Stokes for 10 before Billings’ dismissal, New Zealand – who had taken four wickets for 31 runs – could not capitalise on a brief shift in momentum once Buttler arrived at the crease.

The wicketkeeper was imperious. He scored 129 from 77 balls, including five sixes and 13 fours, battering the Kiwis from one end of the ground to another. The spinners were the main victims, the debutant Mitchell Santner and Nathan McCullum unable to find a chink in Buttler’s armour, but no one was spared.

Boult said of Buttler: “He’s as good as anyone on their day to take apart a bowling unit. Hits all around the ground, which the best players do. Hard to shut down, running in hot form and a significant person to scout.”

He reached his century in 66 balls, the second fastest England ODI in history behind his own 61-ball record set against Sri Lanka last year. It was a devastating display of flair and by the time Buttler skied one from Mitchell McClenaghan and Rashid had added a quickfire 69, England were flying, securing a record seventh-wicket stand.

New Zealand’s task was ominous and, although they began quickly, their desire to score did for them in the end. Finn and Rashid took four wickets apiece, with Taylor the only New Zealand player to reach a half-century. It was all over when McClenaghan found Alex Hales in the deep, drawing a close on England’s best one-day success.

displayImages.caption: Jos Buttler hits out on his way to a blistering 129 as England scored a record 408 for nine in the first ODI against New Zealand at Edgbaston.  Photograph: Shaun Botterill/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England v New Zealand - 1st ODI Royal London One-Day Series 2015
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jos Buttler hits out on his way to a blistering 129 as England scored a record 408 for nine in the first ODI against New Zealand at Edgbaston.  Photograph: Shaun Botterill/Getty Images

headerImage.altText: England v New Zealand - 1st ODI Royal London One-Day Series 2015

cards.title: Rugby union / Toulouse chasing Leicester and England centre Tuilagi
cards.rawTitle: Toulouse chasing Leicester and England centre Tuilagi

item.title: Toulouse chasing Leicester and England centre Manu Tuilagi
item.trailText: Leicester’s Manu Tuilagi is a target for Toulouse, according to reports, and any move would end his hopes of an England return following his assault conviction
item.standFirst:
• Tuilagi is to miss the World Cup due to conviction for assault
• Toulouse are ready to spend big to rebuild their squad
item.body:
Leicester’s Manu Tuilagi is a target for Toulouse, according to reports.

The centre will miss the World Cup for England after having been convicted on three charges of assault, two of which are against female police officers. However, if he were to make the move to France he may have played his last game for England, as Stuart Lancaster has maintained the policy of not selecting those – such as Steffon Armitage (Toulon) and Nick Abendanon (Clermont) – who play outside of England.

Tuilagi is contracted to Leicester until 2017, but the French broadcaster RMC has reported that “contact has been established between the English international and the chairman of the Stade Toulousain, Rene Bouscatel.”

Leicester will be dismayed by the news, having stood by Tuilagi during his latest controversy and in 2011 when he marked the end of the World Cup by jumping from a ferry in Auckland Harbour.

cards.title: Cycling / Wiggins’ team rebut rule-bending accusations in hour record
cards.rawTitle: Wiggins’ team rebut rule-bending accusations in hour record

item.title: Bradley Wiggins’ team rebut rule-bending accusations in hour record
item.trailText: Key members of the team behind Bradley Wiggins’s hour record have poured cold water on claims that his bike broke current regulations
item.standFirst:
• Alex Dowsett’s coach claimed bike ‘wasn’t in production’
• ‘Every bit of bike was approved by UCI,’ says team member
item.body:
Key members of the bike and coaching team behind Sir Bradley Wiggins’ hour record have poured cold water on claims that the aerodynamic bike used to beat Alex Dowsett’s time set in May broke equipment regulations and that he received preferential treatment from British Cycling.

One of Dowsett’s support team, Steve Collins, told BBC Essex that the bike and bars ridden by Wiggins en route to hitting 54.526km for the 60 minutes were not within regulations. “One of the sad bits about it was that Bradley’s bike wasn’t in production,” Collins said.

“For attempts like that it should all be production available so you can buy it off the shelf. You can’t get 3D-printed handlebars moulded to your own arms to make it easier for your own attempt.”

Related: Sir Bradley Wiggins smashes Alex Dowsett’s Hour record

Asked if he thought British Cycling preferred Wiggins to Dowsett, Collins said: “Oh yes, completely.”

Wiggins rode titanium handlebars custom-made through a process similar to 3D printing but which others call “additive manufacturing” on the cycle produced by Pinarello, the Italian bike manufacturer.

“We had to do full documentation for the UCI detailing every component; every bit of the bike and kit was approved by the UCI down to the shoes, helmet and skinsuit. The bike is fully approved by the UCI,” a source close to the Wiggins bid responded. “The handlebars are made under a new manufacturing process, but Pinarello are offering this commercially through their MOST brand. It was the first time this had been done at this level, but a full mountain-bike frame was made in this way last year, and parts for bikes have been made in this way in the US and Australia.”

The Bolide HR used by Wiggins to beat Dowsett’s distance by more than 1.5km can be found on the UCI website on page 14 of its list of approved frames and forks. The entry states that the frame was registered on 21 May this year.

__VIDEO_EMBED_gu-video-457085126__

In a statement, the UCI said in a statement: “Bradley Wiggins’ bike and equipment were thoroughly assessed by UCI officials before and after the UCI Hour Record attempt and were judged to be fully compliant with UCI regulations.”

Custom-made titanium bars similar to those used by Wiggins can be found on the Pinarello website on page eight of a section headlined “Bolide HR’s White Paper”. The text reads: “Standard technologies such as CNC or carbon moulding would be excessively long and expensive to produce this particular shape, so we use an additive manufacturing method also known as 3D printing to manufacture a titanium handlebar.

“The capabilities of this technology allowed to produce [sic] a small batch of handlebars, every one different from the other. This method will be used to provide a similar service to Pinarello customers via the MOST parts brand.”

Heiko Salzwedel, the British Cycling endurance coach who helped Wiggins prepare physically for the hour, rebuffed Collins’ claim that the Olympic gold medallist had received preferential treatment from the governing body. “I’m a GB coach responsible for anyone with a British passport and anyone who asks me will get my support.

“Brad isn’t involved with Team Sky any more, he doesn’t have the resources of a team like Dowsett’s Movistar and in his eyes this was a performance that helped him build to the [2016] Olympic Games so it was natural to help him. I didn’t reduce the time I spent with the team pursuit squad because they were training together; sometimes I spent more time with Brad but that would have been the same if it was Ed Clancy doing a record.

“If Alex had asked me I’d have helped him, but he didn’t. He asked for his training times at Manchester and got them free of charge.”

displayImages.caption: Bradley Wiggins gets his head down on his custom-built bike as he sets the hour record at the Velodrome. Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bradley Wiggins gets his head down on his custom-built bike as he sets the hour record at the Velodrome. Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
